title: How to Puree Blueberries

methods.name: Making Plain Blueberry Puree for Babies

steps.headline: Buy organic blueberries that are either fresh or frozen.
steps.description: Blueberries are summer fruits, so buy them fresh if they’re in season. Otherwise, it’s perfectly fine to use frozen blueberries! Organic blueberries are the best choice for baby food, since non-organic blueberries are known to have a lot of pesticide residue. ½ cup (50 g) of fresh or frozen blueberries yields about 4 ounces (118 ml) of puree. Blueberry puree is easy to store, so feel free to make a large batch! If you’re buying fresh blueberries, choose the ripest berries available. Ripe blueberries are plump, uniformly purple, and free of bruises.

steps.headline: Rinse fresh blueberries thoroughly with cool water.
steps.description: Discard any blueberries that look discolored or damaged and place them in a colander. Run cool water over the berries to remove dirt or debris. Shake the colander a bit or move the berries around with your fingers to make sure all of them are rinsed thoroughly. Frozen blueberries usually don’t need to be rinsed off.

steps.headline: Steam unripe or frozen blueberries for 3 minutes to soften them.
steps.description: For frozen or under-ripened berries, place them in a steamer and heat them for about 3 minutes to make them pliable. Once they’re soft, drain the berries and rinse them with cold water to stop the cooking process. If your blueberries are fresh and ripe, you can skip this step.

steps.headline: Process the blueberries in a blender for 90 seconds for smooth puree.
steps.description: Smooth puree is best for babies under the age of 10 months. Place the blueberries in a blender or a food processor and puree them on HIGH for about 90 seconds. Stop the blender every 20 seconds or so to scrape down the sides with a spoon or spatula. If the consistency is too thick or your blender is having trouble processing the fruit, add a spoonful of water and try again.Alternative: Process the blueberries with banana and avocado for a creamy treat! Place 1 cup (100 g) of fresh blueberries, 1 banana, and 1/2 an avocado into your blender. Add 1 teaspoon (4.9 ml) of fresh lemon juice and blend the ingredients on HIGH for 1-2 minutes. Pause the blender to scrape down the sides every 30 seconds or so, as needed.

steps.headline: Mash the blueberries with a potato masher for chunky puree.
steps.description: For babies over the age of 10 months, chunky blueberry puree is ideal. Put the blueberries in a large bowl and press down on them firmly with a manual potato masher tool for 30-60 seconds. Stop once you're happy with the consistency of the puree.

steps.headline: Serve the blueberry puree plain or mix it into oatmeal or yogurt.
steps.description: Plain blueberry puree is tasty as long as the blueberries are ripe and sweet. If the blueberries are on the tart side, try mixing the puree into a bowl of oatmeal or into a cup of yogurt. Blueberry puree is also delicious in applesauce! Store leftover blueberry puree in an airtight container in your fridge. Be sure to use it within 3 days. You can also freeze the blueberry puree for up to 4 months.

methods.name: Whipping up Blueberry Puree for Cocktails

steps.headline: Rinse 2 cups (200 g) of fresh blueberries with cool water.
steps.description: Choose plump, ripe blueberries from your local grocery store during the summer season for the tastiest berries. Place them in a colander and run cool, fresh water over them to remove dirt and debris. For this recipe, fresh blueberries work much better than the frozen variety. However, feel free to use frozen berries if that's all you have access to.

steps.headline: Place the blueberries in your blender with the lemon juice and sugar.
steps.description: Transfer the clean blueberries to your blender. Add 2 tablespoons (30 ml) of fresh lemon juice and 2 teaspoons (8.4 g) of white granulated sugar to the blender. Position the lid on the blender securely. If you prefer, you can use 2 teaspoons (9.9 ml) of simple syrup instead of the white granulated sugar. Use store-bought lemon juice if you don't have fresh lemons on hand.

steps.headline: Process the ingredients for 90 seconds until the mixture is smooth.
steps.description: Turn the blender on HIGH and puree the ingredients for 90 seconds or up to 2 minutes. Stop the blender every 20 seconds or so to scrape down the sides. This ensures an even puree.

steps.headline: Mix the puree into your favorite summer cocktails.
steps.description: You can use as much or as little blueberry puree as you like! Simply add the puree to the cocktail shaker with the other ingredients and shake them up as you normally would. Blueberry puree works wonderfully in summer cocktails like spiked lemonade, margaritas, and sangria. Refrigerate leftover blueberry puree for up to 3 days in an airtight container.

tyn: Blender, food processor, or potato masher
text: Making Plain Blueberry Puree for Babies Buy organic blueberries that are either fresh or frozen. Blueberries are summer fruits, so buy them fresh if they’re in season. Otherwise, it’s perfectly fine to use frozen blueberries! Organic blueberries are the best choice for baby food, since non-organic blueberries are known to have a lot of pesticide residue. ½ cup (50 g) of fresh or frozen blueberries yields about 4 ounces (118 ml) of puree. Blueberry puree is easy to store, so feel free to make a large batch! If you’re buying fresh blueberries, choose the ripest berries available. Ripe blueberries are plump, uniformly purple, and free of bruises. Rinse fresh blueberries thoroughly with cool water. Discard any blueberries that look discolored or damaged and place them in a colander. Run cool water over the berries to remove dirt or debris. Shake the colander a bit or move the berries around with your fingers to make sure all of them are rinsed thoroughly. Frozen blueberries usually don’t need to be rinsed off. Steam unripe or frozen blueberries for 3 minutes to soften them. For frozen or under-ripened berries, place them in a steamer and heat them for about 3 minutes to make them pliable. Once they’re soft, drain the berries and rinse them with cold water to stop the cooking process. If your blueberries are fresh and ripe, you can skip this step. Process the blueberries in a blender for 90 seconds for smooth puree. Smooth puree is best for babies under the age of 10 months. Place the blueberries in a blender or a food processor and puree them on HIGH for about 90 seconds. Stop the blender every 20 seconds or so to scrape down the sides with a spoon or spatula. If the consistency is too thick or your blender is having trouble processing the fruit, add a spoonful of water and try again.Alternative: Process the blueberries with banana and avocado for a creamy treat! Place 1 cup (100 g) of fresh blueberries, 1 banana, and 1/2 an avocado into your blender. Add 1 teaspoon (4.9 ml) of fresh lemon juice and blend the ingredients on HIGH for 1-2 minutes. Pause the blender to scrape down the sides every 30 seconds or so, as needed. Mash the blueberries with a potato masher for chunky puree. For babies over the age of 10 months, chunky blueberry puree is ideal. Put the blueberries in a large bowl and press down on them firmly with a manual potato masher tool for 30-60 seconds. Stop once you're happy with the consistency of the puree. Serve the blueberry puree plain or mix it into oatmeal or yogurt. Plain blueberry puree is tasty as long as the blueberries are ripe and sweet. If the blueberries are on the tart side, try mixing the puree into a bowl of oatmeal or into a cup of yogurt. Blueberry puree is also delicious in applesauce! Store leftover blueberry puree in an airtight container in your fridge. Be sure to use it within 3 days. You can also freeze the blueberry puree for up to 4 months. Whipping up Blueberry Puree for Cocktails Rinse 2 cups (200 g) of fresh blueberries with cool water. Choose plump, ripe blueberries from your local grocery store during the summer season for the tastiest berries. Place them in a colander and run cool, fresh water over them to remove dirt and debris. For this recipe, fresh blueberries work much better than the frozen variety. However, feel free to use frozen berries if that's all you have access to. Place the blueberries in your blender with the lemon juice and sugar. Transfer the clean blueberries to your blender. Add 2 tablespoons (30 ml) of fresh lemon juice and 2 teaspoons (8.4 g) of white granulated sugar to the blender. Position the lid on the blender securely. If you prefer, you can use 2 teaspoons (9.9 ml) of simple syrup instead of the white granulated sugar. Use store-bought lemon juice if you don't have fresh lemons on hand. Process the ingredients for 90 seconds until the mixture is smooth. Turn the blender on HIGH and puree the ingredients for 90 seconds or up to 2 minutes. Stop the blender every 20 seconds or so to scrape down the sides. This ensures an even puree. Mix the puree into your favorite summer cocktails. You can use as much or as little blueberry puree as you like! Simply add the puree to the cocktail shaker with the other ingredients and shake them up as you normally would. Blueberry puree works wonderfully in summer cocktails like spiked lemonade, margaritas, and sangria. Refrigerate leftover blueberry puree for up to 3 days in an airtight container.

Blueberries are summer fruits, so buy them fresh if they’re in season.
Otherwise, it’s perfectly fine to use frozen blueberries!
Organic blueberries are the best choice for baby food, since non-organic blueberries are known to have a lot of pesticide residue.

Blueberry puree is easy to store, so feel free to make a large batch!

Frozen blueberries usually don’t need to be rinsed off.

For frozen or under-ripened berries, place them in a steamer and heat them for about 3 minutes to make them pliable.
Once they’re soft, drain the berries and rinse them with cold water to stop the cooking process.
If your blueberries are fresh and ripe, you can skip this step.
Process the blueberries in a blender for 90 seconds for smooth puree.
Smooth puree is best for babies under the age of 10 months.

If the consistency is too thick or your blender is having trouble processing the fruit, add a spoonful of water and try again.Alternative: Process the blueberries with banana and avocado for a creamy treat!
Place 1 cup (100 g) of fresh blueberries, 1 banana, and 1/2 an avocado into your blender.

Stop once you're happy with the consistency of the puree.
Serve the blueberry puree plain or mix it into oatmeal or yogurt.
Plain blueberry puree is tasty as long as the blueberries are ripe and sweet.

Blueberry puree is also delicious in applesauce!
Store leftover blueberry puree in an airtight container in your fridge.
Be sure to use it within 3 days.
You can also freeze the blueberry puree for up to 4 months.
Whipping up Blueberry Puree for Cocktails Rinse 2 cups (200 g) of fresh blueberries with cool water.
Choose plump, ripe blueberries from your local grocery store during the summer season for the tastiest berries.
Place them in a colander and run cool, fresh water over them to remove dirt and debris.
For this recipe, fresh blueberries work much better than the frozen variety.
However, feel free to use frozen berries if that's all you have access to.
Place the blueberries in your blender with the lemon juice and sugar.
Transfer the clean blueberries to your blender.
Add 2 tablespoons (30 ml) of fresh lemon juice and 2 teaspoons (8.4 g) of white granulated sugar to the blender.
Position the lid on the blender securely.
If you prefer, you can use 2 teaspoons (9.9 ml) of simple syrup instead of the white granulated sugar.
Use store-bought lemon juice if you don't have fresh lemons on hand.
Process the ingredients for 90 seconds until the mixture is smooth.
Turn the blender on HIGH and puree the ingredients for 90 seconds or up to 2 minutes.
Stop the blender every 20 seconds or so to scrape down the sides.
This ensures an even puree.
Mix the puree into your favorite summer cocktails.
You can use as much or as little blueberry puree as you like!
Simply add the puree to the cocktail shaker with the other ingredients and shake them up as you normally would.
Blueberry puree works wonderfully in summer cocktails like spiked lemonade, margaritas, and sangria.
Refrigerate leftover blueberry puree for up to 3 days in an airtight container.
